text: my name is Alexis fuge and I'm the
Engagement Manager for worldwide
sustainability at Amazon in the
worldwide sustainability organization at
Amazon we are looking at our systems
from end to end and we're looking at
them with an eye towards what the
environmental and social impacts of
those processes are and where we see
opportunities to reduce and mitigate
those Joe before you throw was a
hackathon project that I've worked with
about six other members and we utilized
the capabilities of the AWS deep lens
device to solve a real world issue of
not knowing where to put your trash so
the idea was you show the deep lens your
trash and the deep lines tells you where
to throw it it will tell you if that
item needs to go into the compost bin
the landfill bin or the recycle bin
seeing as a lot of money and times and
human labor is spent on sorting trash
every year every day every week we felt
that this was the problem that deserved
to be taken up and in our small way
through this hackathon we thought we
could we could try and see what could be
done the impact of that is is
non-trivial and actually even heightened
in this particular day and age because
contaminated recycling doesn't get
disposed of as recycling it ultimately
gets disposed of in the landfill for
people who are using or looking to use
the deep lens camera to have an impact
there's a big opportunity to really
think big about where those impacts can
be had there is an emphasis on the
ability to kind of intercept
decision-making and/or to make informed
decision making by using a machine
learning enabled camera so we invite
everybody out there to really think big
about the way that the AWS deep lens
camera can help enable and actually
impact very positively are our world
[Music]
